children.value: In this chapter, we will learn how to extend our description of an object’s motion to two and three dimensions by using vectors. We will also consider the specific case of an object moving along the circumference of a circle.
Using vectors to describe motion in two dimensions

children.label: Using vectors to describe motion in two dimensions

children.value: We can specify the location of an object with its coordinates, and we can describe any displacement by a vector. First, consider the case of an object moving with a constant velocity in a particular direction. We can specify the position of the object at any time,

children.html: ttt
r⃗(t)\vec r(t)r(t)

children.value: , which is a function of time. The position vector is a vector that goes from the origin of the coordinate system to the position of the object. We can describe the

children.html: xxx
yyy

y(t)y(t)y(t)

children.value: The average velocity vector will have the same direction as

children.html: Δr⃗\Delta \vec rΔr

children.value: , since it is the displacement vector divided by a scalar (

children.html: Δt\Delta tΔt

children.value: ). The magnitude of the velocity vector, which we call “speed”, will be proportional to the length of the displacement vector. If the object moves a large distance in a small amount of time, it will thus have a large velocity vector. This definition of the velocity vector thus has the correct intuitive properties (points in the direction of motion, is larger for faster objects).
For example, if the object went from position

children.value: which again shows that two dimensional motion can be considered as separate and independent motions in each direction.

children.value: As an example, consider the situation depicted in Figure
. Brice is on a boat off the shore of Nice, with a coordinate system

children.html: xyxyxy

children.value: , and is describing the position of a boat carrying Alice. He describes Alice’s position as

children.html: r⃗A(t)\vec r^A(t)rA(t)
xyxyxy

children.value: coordinate system. Igor is on the shore and also wishes to describe Alice’s position using the work done by Brice. Igor sees Brice’s boat move with a velocity

children.value: Example of converting from one reference frame to another in two dimensions using vector addition.
Writing this out by coordinate, we have:

children.html: x′A(t)=vx′Bt+xA(t)y′A(t)=vy′Bt+yA(t)\begin{align*} x'^A(t)&=v'^B_xt+x^A(t)\\ y'^A(t)&=v'^B_yt+y^A(t) \end{align*}x′A(t)y′A(t)​=vx′B​t+xA(t)=vy′B​t+yA(t)​
vx′A(t)=vx′B+vxA(t)vy′A(t)=vy′B+vyA(t)\begin{align*} v_x'^A(t)&=v'^B_x+v_x^A(t)\\ v_y'^A(t)&=v'^B_y+v_y^A(t) \end{align*}vx′A​(t)vy′A​(t)​=vx′B​+vxA​(t)=vy′B​+vyA​(t)​

children.value: The big challenge was to expand our description of motion from one dimension to two. Adding a third dimension ends up being trivial now that we know how to use vectors. In three dimensions, we describe the position of a point using three coordinates, so all of the vectors simply have three independent components, but are treated in exactly the same way as in the two dimensional case. The position of an object is now described by three independent functions,

children.html: x(t)x(t)x(t)
y(t)y(t)y(t)
z(t)z(t)z(t)

children.value: , that make up the three components of a position vector

children.html: r⃗(t)\vec r(t)r(t)

r⃗(t)=(x(t)y(t)z(t))∴r⃗(t)=x(t)x^+y(t)y^+z(t)z^\begin{align*} \vec r(t) &= \begin{pmatrix} x(t) \\ y(t) \\ z(t) \\ \end{pmatrix}\\ \therefore \vec r(t) &= x(t) \hat x + y(t) \hat y + z(t) \hat z \end{align*}r(t)∴r(t)​=⎝⎛​x(t)y(t)z(t)​⎠⎞​=x(t)x^+y(t)y^​+z(t)z^​

children.value: The velocity vector now has three components and is defined analogously to the 2D case:

children.html: v⃗(t)=dr⃗dt=(dxdtdydtdzdt)=(vx(t)vy(t)vz(t))∴v⃗(t)=vx(t)x^+vy(t)y^+vz(t)z^\begin{align*} \vec v(t) &=\frac{d\vec r}{dt} =\begin{pmatrix} \frac{dx}{dt} \\ \frac{dy}{dt} \\ \frac{dz}{dt} \\ \end{pmatrix} =\begin{pmatrix} v_x(t) \\ v_y(t) \\ v_z(t) \\ \end{pmatrix}\\ \therefore \vec v(t) &= v_x(t)\hat x+v_y(t)\hat y+v_z(t)\hat z \nonumber \end{align*}v(t)∴v(t)​=dtdr​=⎝⎛​dtdx​dtdy​dtdz​​⎠⎞​=⎝⎛​vx​(t)vy​(t)vz​(t)​⎠⎞​=vx​(t)x^+vy​(t)y^​+vz​(t)z^​

children.value: and the acceleration is defined in a similar way:

children.html: a⃗(t)=dv⃗dt=(dvxdtdvydtdvzdt)=(ax(t)ay(t)az(t))∴a⃗(t)=ax(t)x^+ay(t)y^+az(t)z^\begin{align*} \vec a(t) &=\frac{d\vec v}{dt} =\begin{pmatrix} \frac{dv_x}{dt} \\ \frac{dv_y}{dt} \\ \frac{dv_z}{dt} \\ \end{pmatrix} =\begin{pmatrix} a_x(t) \\ a_y(t) \\ a_z(t) \\ \end{pmatrix}\\ \therefore \vec a(t) &= a_x(t)\hat x+a_y(t)\hat y+a_z(t)\hat z \nonumber \end{align*}a(t)∴a(t)​=dtdv​=⎝⎛​dtdvx​​dtdvy​​dtdvz​​​⎠⎞​=⎝⎛​ax​(t)ay​(t)az​(t)​⎠⎞​=ax​(t)x^+ay​(t)y^​+az​(t)z^​

children.value: In particular, if an object has a constant acceleration,

children.html: a⃗=axx^+ayy^+azz^\vec a=a_x\hat x+a_y\hat y+a_z\hat za=ax​x^+ay​y^​+az​z^
t=0t=0t=0
r⃗0\vec r_0r0​
v⃗0\vec v_0v0​

children.value: , then its velocity vector is given by:

children.html: v⃗(t)=v⃗0+a⃗t=(v0x+axtv0y+aytv0z+azt)\begin{align*} \vec v(t) &= \vec v_0+\vec at=\begin{pmatrix} v_{0x}+ a_xt \\ v_{0y}+ a_yt \\ v_{0z}+ a_zt \\ \end{pmatrix}\\ \end{align*}v(t)​=v0​+at=⎝⎛​v0x​+ax​tv0y​+ay​tv0z​+az​t​⎠⎞​​

children.value: and the position vector is given by:

children.html: r⃗(t)=r⃗0+v⃗0t+12a⃗t2=(x0+v0xt+12axt2y0+v0yt+12ayt2z0+v0zt+12azt2)\begin{align*} \vec r(t)= \vec r_0+\vec v_0 t+\frac{1}{2}\vec a t^2=\begin{pmatrix} x_0+v_{0x}t+\frac{1}{2} a_xt^2 \\ y_0+v_{0y}t+\frac{1}{2} a_yt^2 \\ z_0+v_{0z}t+\frac{1}{2} a_zt^2 \\ \end{pmatrix}\\ \end{align*}r(t)=r0​+v0​t+21​at2=⎝⎛​x0​+v0x​t+21​ax​t2y0​+v0y​t+21​ay​t2z0​+v0z​t+21​az​t2​⎠⎞​​

children.value: where again, we see how writing a single vector equation (e.g.

children.html: v⃗(t)=v⃗0+a⃗t\vec v(t) = \vec v_0+\vec atv(t)=v0​+at

children.value: ) is really just a way to write the three independent equations that are true for each component.
Accelerated motion when the velocity vector changes direction
One key difference with one dimensional motion is that, in two dimensions, it is possible to have an acceleration even when the speed is constant. Recall, the acceleration
is defined as the time derivative of the velocity
). This means that if the velocity vector changes with time, then the acceleration vector is non-zero. If the length of the velocity vector (speed) is constant, it is still possible that the

of the velocity vector changes with time, and thus, that the acceleration vector is non-zero. This is, for example, what happens when an object goes around in a circle with a constant speed (the direction of the velocity vector changes).
Illustration of how the direction of the velocity vector can change when speed is constant.
shows an illustration of a velocity vector,

v⃗1\vec v_1v1​
v⃗2\vec v_2v2​

children.value: , between the two. In this case, the length of the velocity vector did not change with time (

children.html: ∣∣v⃗1∣∣=∣∣v⃗2∣∣||\vec v_1||=||\vec v_2||∣∣v1​∣∣=∣∣v2​∣∣

children.value: ). The acceleration vector is given by:

children.html: a⃗=lim⁡Δt→0Δv⃗Δt\begin{align*} \vec a = \lim_{\Delta t\to 0}\frac{\Delta \vec v}{\Delta t} \end{align*}a=Δt→0lim​ΔtΔv​​

children.html: Δv\Delta vΔv

children.value: . Thus, even if the velocity vector does not change amplitude (speed is constant), the acceleration vector can be non-zero if the velocity vector changes
Let us write the velocity vector,

children.html: v⃗\vec vv
vvv

v⃗=vxx^+vyy^=vv^v=∣∣v⃗∣∣=vx2+vy2v^=vxvx^+vyvy^\begin{align*} \vec v &=v_x\hat x+v_y\hat y= v \hat v\\ v&=||\vec v||=\sqrt{v_x^2+v_y^2}\\ \hat v &= \frac{v_x}{v}\hat x+\frac{v_y}{v}\hat y\\ \end{align*}vvv^​=vx​x^+vy​y^​=vv^=∣∣v∣∣=vx2​+vy2​​=vvx​​x^+vvy​​y^​​

children.value: In the most general case, both the magnitude of the velocity and its direction can change with time. That is, both the direction and the magnitude of the velocity vector are functions of time:

children.html: v⃗(t)=v(t)v^(t)\begin{align*} \vec v(t)&=v(t)\hat v(t) \end{align*}v(t)​=v(t)v^(t)​

children.value: When we take the time derivative of

children.html: v⃗(t)\vec v(t)v(t)

children.value: to obtain the acceleration vector, we need to take the derivative of a product of two functions of time,

children.html: v(t)v(t)v(t)
v^(t)\hat v(t)v^(t)

children.value: . Using the rules for taking the derivative of a product, the acceleration vector is given by:

children.label: eqn:describingmotioninnd:avecdef2

children.value: and has two terms. The first term,

children.html: dvdtv^(t)\frac{dv}{dt}\hat v(t)dtdv​v^(t)

children.value: , is zero if the speed is constant (

children.html: dvdt=0\frac{dv}{dt}=0dtdv​=0
v(t)dv^dtv(t)\frac{d\hat v}{dt}v(t)dtdv^​

children.value: , is zero if the direction of the velocity vector is constant (

children.html: dv^dt=0\frac{d\hat v}{dt}=0dtdv^​=0

children.value: ). In general though, the acceleration vector has two terms corresponding to the change in speed, and to the change in the direction of the velocity, respectively.
The specific functional form of the acceleration vector will depend on the path being taken by the object. If we consider the case where speed is constant, then we have:

children.html: v(t)=vdvdt=0vx2(t)+vy2(t)=v2∴vy(t)=v2−vx(t)2\begin{align*} v(t) &= v \\ \frac{dv}{dt}&=0\\ v_x^2(t)+v_y^2(t) &=v^2 \\ \therefore v_y(t)&=\sqrt{v^2-v_x(t)^2} \end{align*}v(t)dtdv​vx2​(t)+vy2​(t)∴vy​(t)​=v=0=v2=v2−vx​(t)2​​

yyy

We often consider the motion of an object around a circle of fixed radius,

children.html: RRR

children.value: . In principle, this is motion in two dimensions, as a circle is necessarily in a two dimensional plane. However, since the object is constrained to move along the circumference of the circle, it can be thought of (and treated as) motion along a one dimensional axis that is curved.
Describing the motion of an object around a circle of radius

children.html: v⃗(t)=ddtr⃗(t)=ddtR(cos⁡(θ(t))sin⁡(θ(t)))=R(ddtcos⁡(θ(t))ddtsin⁡(θ(t)))=R(−sin⁡(θ(t))dθdtcos⁡(θ(t))dθdt)\begin{align*} \vec v(t) &=\frac{d}{dt}\vec r(t) =\frac{d}{dt} R \begin{pmatrix} \cos(\theta(t)) \\ \sin(\theta(t)) \\ \end{pmatrix} \\ &= R \begin{pmatrix} \frac{d}{dt}\cos(\theta(t)) \\ \frac{d}{dt}\sin(\theta(t)) \\ \end{pmatrix} \\ &= R \begin{pmatrix} -\sin(\theta(t))\frac{d\theta}{dt} \\ \cos(\theta(t))\frac{d\theta}{dt} \\ \end{pmatrix} \\ \end{align*}v(t)​=dtd​r(t)=dtd​R(cos(θ(t))sin(θ(t))​)=R(dtd​cos(θ(t))dtd​sin(θ(t))​)=R(−sin(θ(t))dtdθ​cos(θ(t))dtdθ​​)​

children.value: That is, the component of the acceleration vector that is parallel to the velocity is precisely the acceleration in the

children.html: sss

children.value: direction (the linear acceleration). This component of the acceleration is responsible for increasing (or decreasing) the speed of the object and is zero if the object goes around the circle with a constant speed (linear or angular).
As we saw earlier, the perpendicular component of the acceleration,

children.html: a⃗⊥(t)\vec a_{\bot}(t)a⊥​(t)

children.value: , is responsible for changing the direction of the velocity vector (as the object continuously changes direction when going in a circle). When the motion is around a circle, this component of the acceleration vector is called “centripetal” acceleration (i.e. acceleration pointing towards the centre of the circle, as we will see). We can calculate the centripetal acceleration in terms of our angular variables, noting that the unit vector in the direction of the velocity is

children.html: v^=−sin⁡(θ)x^+cos⁡(θ)y^\hat v=-\sin(\theta)\hat x+\cos(\theta)\hat yv^=−sin(θ)x^+cos(θ)y^​

children.value: has unit length and points towards the centre of the circle (when the tail is placed on a point on the circle at angle
). The centripetal acceleration thus points towards the centre of the circle and has magnitude:

children.html: ac(t)=∣∣a⃗⊥(t)∣∣=ω2(t)R=v2(t)R\begin{align} a_c(t) = ||\vec a_{\bot}(t)||=\omega^2(t) R = \frac{v^2(t)}{R} \end{align}ac​(t)=∣∣a⊥​(t)∣∣=ω2(t)R=Rv2(t)​​​

children.value: where in the last equal sign, we wrote the centripetal acceleration in terms of the speed around the circle (

children.html: v=∣∣v⃗∣∣=vsv=||\vec v||=v_sv=∣∣v∣∣=vs​

children.value: If an object goes around a circle, it will always have a centripetal acceleration (since its velocity vector must change direction). In addition, if the object’s speed is changing, it will also have a linear acceleration, which points in the same direction as the velocity vector (it changes the velocity vector’s length but not its direction).

When an object is moving around in a circle, it will typically complete more than one revolution. If the object is going around the circle with a constant speed, we call the motion “uniform circular motion”, and we can define the

children.html: TTT

children.value: , is defined to be the time that it takes to complete one revolution around the circle. If the object has constant angular speed

children.html: TTT

children.value: . Think of frequency as the number of revolutions completed per second. Thus, if the frequency is

children.message: Undefined control sequence: \SI at position 3: f=\̲S̲I̲{1}{Hz}

children.value: , the object goes around the circle once per second. Given the frequency, we can of course obtain the angular velocity:

children.html: ω=2πf\begin{align*} \omega = 2\pi f \end{align*}ω=2πf​

children.value: which is sometimes called the “angular frequency” instead of the angular velocity. The angular velocity can really be thought of as a frequency, as it represents the “amount of angle” per second that an object covers when going around a circle. The angular velocity does not tell us anything about the actual speed of the object, which depends on the radius

children.html: v=ωRv=\omega Rv=ωR

children.value: , where two objects can be travelling around two circles of radius

children.html: R1R_1R1​
R2R_2R2​

children.value: . If they have the same angular velocity, then it will take them the same amount of time to complete a revolution. However, the outer object has to cover a much larger distance (the circumference is larger), and thus has to move with a larger linear speed.
For a given angular velocity, the linear velocity will be larger on a larger circle (
